Australia: The Convention agreed on a final draft to be put to the people.

After much public debate, the Victorian, South Australian and Tasmanian referendums were successful; the New South Wales referendum narrowly failed. Later New South Wales voted "yes" in a second referendum.
Brazil: In the presidential election, Manuel Ferraz de Campos Sales of the Republican Party of São Paulo, is successful, with 90.9% of the vote.
China: Hundred Days' Reform: The Guangxu Emperor instituted reforms including radical changes in the imperial examination and the elimination of sinecures.
The Guangxu Emperor was removed from the imperial palace in a coup organized by Cixi and Ronglu, the Viceroy of Zhili.
Colombia: Manuel Antonio Sanclemente is the 7th president of Colombia
Cuba: The battleship USS Maine explodes and sinks while anchored in Havana harbor.
The Treaty of Paris between Spain and the U.S. ends the Spanish–American War. Spain relinquishes sovereignty over Cuba.
Cyprus: Sir William Frederick Haynes Smith became Crown commissioner.
Indinesia: General van Heutz becomes chief of staff of Aceh campaign. Wilhelmina becomes queen of the Netherlands.
Philippine: The only issue of Kalayaan is published; official organ of the Katipunan.
The American Soldier and The Soldier's Letter are published; first English language newspapers.
Official Gazette is established by the civil government.
The Katipunan is revived by Emilio Jacinto and Feliciano Jocson
A revolutionary government in Candon, Ilocos Sur was established by Don Isabelo Abaya as he started Cry of Candon.
Basilio Augustín appointed Governor-General (1898)
The US government promises support in exchange for his cooperation. Aguinaldo agrees
The US declares war on Spain.
Commodore George Dewey attacks Manila
Aguinaldo and his companions return to the Philippines from exile
Aguinaldo proclaims a dictatorial government and issues two decrees which show his trust and reliance in US protection
Aguinaldo proclaims Philippine Independence
Aguinaldo changes the dictatorial government to revolutionary government.
Aguinaldo creates a cabinet
The Malolos Congress in established
US reinforcements and troops arrive in the Philippines.
Fermín Jáudenes becomes acting Governor-General (1898)
Francisco Rizzo becomes acting Governor-General (1898)
Wesley Merritt appointed Military Governor (1898)
The Spanish surrender to the US after at mock battle of Manila
Elwell S. Otis appointed Military Governor (1898–1900)
Diego de los Ríos becomes acting Governor-General (1898)
The Malolos Congress meets and elects its officers.
The Manila Times is founded by Thomas Cowan and publishes its first issue; the country's oldest running broadsheet; its first incarnation lasted 32 years.
The American is published by Franklyn Brooks; second English language daily paper.
Republic of Negros is proclaimed by revolutionary movement under Gen. Aniceto Lacson and Gen. Juan Araneta in Bago, Negros Occidental; its Constitution promulgated, Nov. 7.
Spain and the U.S. sign the Treaty of Paris. Article III provides for the cession of the Philippines to the U.S. by Spain and the payment of 20 million dollars to Spain by the US.
US President McKinley issues the Benevolent Assimilation Proclamation
Gov.-Gen. de los Rios surrenders the town of Iloilo to revolutionary forces led by Gen. Martin Delgado.
Poland: The Volunteer Fire Department was founded.
Russia: The Marxist Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (RSDLP) held its first Party Congress.
Slovenia: The railway line on the route Ljubljana – Kočevje is built.
Sweden: The formation of the Swedish Trade Union Confederation (LO).
Tanzania: Following years of resistance, Chief Mkwawa of the Hehe is cornered by German soldiers and commits suicide in lieu of capture.
USA: The USS Maine exploded in Havana harbor.
The De Lôme Letter was published.
Spanish–American War: The Treaty of Paris (1898) ended the war.
The Republic of Hawaii was annexed.
The American Anti-Imperialist League was organized.
